structured_info.title_cn: 基于复值神经网络和网络压缩的高效特定发射机识别方法
structured_info.title_en: An Efficient Specific Emitter Identification Method Based on Complex-Valued Neural Networks and Network Compression
structured_info.abstract: Specific emitter identification (SEI) is a promising technology to discriminate the individual emitter and enhance the security of various wireless communication systems. SEI is generally based on radio frequency fingerprinting (RFF) originated from the imperfection of emitter's hardware, which is difficult to forge. SEI is generally modeled as a classification task and deep learning (DL), which exhibits powerful classification capability, has been introduced into SEI for better identification performance. In the recent years, a novel DL model, named as complex-valued neural network (CVNN), has been applied into SEI methods for directly processing complex baseband signal and improving identification performance, but it also brings high model complexity and large model size, which is not conducive to the deployment of SEI, especially in Internet-of-things (IoT) scenarios. Thus, we propose an efficient SEI method based on CVNN and network compression, and the former is for performance improvement, while the latter is to reduce model complexity and size with ensuring satisfactory identification performance. Simulation results demonstrated that our proposed CVNN-based SEI method is superior to the existing DL-based methods in both identification performance and convergence speed, and the identification accuracy of CVNN can reach up to nearly 100% at high signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs). In addition, SlimCVNN just has 10%~30% model sizes of the basic CVNN, and its computing complexity has different degrees of decline at different SNRs; there is almost no performance gap between SlimCVNN and CVNN. These results demonstrated the feasibility and potential of CVNN and model compression.
structured_info.methodology: The paper proposes an efficient SEI method based on CVNN and network compression. The methodology includes designing a basic CVCNN model, applying a sparse structure selection (Triple-S) algorithm for network compression, and using knowledge distillation (KD) to recover performance loss.
structured_info.conclusion: The proposed CVNN-based SEI method achieves nearly perfect identification accuracy at high SNRs and outperforms existing CNN-based SEI methods in both identification performance and convergence speed. The SlimCVNN model reduces complexity and size significantly while maintaining performance, demonstrating the feasibility of CVNN and model compression in SEI applications.
structured_info.venue: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications

analysis.Overview: The paper presents an efficient specific emitter identification (SEI) method using complex-valued neural networks (CVNN) and network compression techniques to enhance performance and reduce computational complexity.
Background_and_Motivation: SEI is crucial for enhancing wireless communication security by identifying individual emitters based on unique radio frequency fingerprints (RFF).
Traditional SEI methods face challenges in processing complex baseband signals and high computational complexity.
The authors argue for the necessity of CVNN to directly process complex signals and network compression to reduce model size for IoT applications.
The research addresses the broader challenge of secure and efficient wireless communication systems.
The paper contributes to wireless communications, deep learning, and signal processing fields.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include CVNN for direct complex signal processing, Triple-S for network compression, and KD for performance recovery.
CVNN processes complex signals directly, Triple-S reduces model size, and KD transfers knowledge from a larger model.
Assumes RFF is unique and hardware-based, and CVNN can outperform real-valued networks.
The paper contributes a novel SEI method combining CVNN and compression, advancing the field of wireless security.
Methodology: Uses CVNN for SEI, Triple-S for compression, and KD for performance recovery.
CVNN's novelty lies in direct complex signal processing; Triple-S and KD are adapted from existing methods.
Data is collected from real wireless signals with added AWGN, preprocessed for normalization.
Experiments are rigorous with multiple SNRs and comparative baselines.
Follows deep learning and signal processing paradigms, focusing on practical deployment.
Results: CVNN achieves near 100% accuracy at high SNRs; SlimCVNN reduces model size by 70-90% with minimal performance loss.
Results are reliable, demonstrated across various SNRs and compared with existing methods.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Structured to first justify CVNN, then introduce compression, and validate with experiments.
Key steps: CVNN design, Triple-S application, KD for recovery, and performance evaluation.
Strengths: comprehensive validation; weaknesses: limited real-world testing.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Innovations: CVNN for SEI, Triple-S, and KD integration.
Limitations: Performance degrades at low SNRs; assumes ideal conditions.
Theoretical focus on CVNN may limit generalizability to other network types.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positions within wireless security and deep learning discourse.
Uses technical terminology and citations to establish authority and justify methods.
Conclusions_and_Implications: CVNN and compression effectively improve SEI performance and efficiency.
Future work: Extend to more complex environments and real-time applications.
